item.title: Emerging Market Currencies Gain as Investors See ‘Stars Align’
item.description: Emerging market currencies gained as President Donald Trump’s move to extend a deadline for aggressive tariffs on the European Union bolstered risk appetite, while trading volumes remained thin due to holidays in the US and the UK.

item.title: Stocks Rise on Trump’s Tariff Delay; Dollar Wavers: Markets Wrap

item.title: India NSE Plans to Seek Tuesday Expiry for Derivatives Contracts
item.description: The exchange that handles the highest number of derivatives contracts in the world plans to apply to change its expiry date to Tuesday from Thursday, according to a person with knowledge of the matter, pitting itself directly against its rival to clawback market share as the regulator seeks to curb excessive trading.

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodities This Week
item.description: Chicken is going to be harder to come by in markets from China to Europe after a case of bird flu was detected in top exporter Brazil. Summer is just around the corner in the Northern Hemisphere, prompting forecasts for hurricanes as well as predictions about gasoline demand in the US. And the Democratic Republic of the Congo — dubbed the “Saudi Arabia of cobalt” — is becoming a player in the trade war between China and the US.
item.dc:creator: Clarice Couto, Brian K Sullivan, Will Wade

media:content.media:description: ISA Brown chickens in a chicken coop at an egg farm in Mason, Michigan, US, on Monday, March 3, 2025. Egg prices have soared to a record of over $8 a dozen, driven by the worst-ever outbreak of avian flu in the US and contributing to broader inflation pressures.

item.title: Dai-Ichi Life Sees JGB Market Volatility Declining by Year End
item.description: The surging bond yields that have saddled Japan’s insurers with billions of dollars in unrealized losses will weaken because they are not supported by economic fundamentals, according to Dai-ichi Life Holdings Inc., the country’s largest listed life insurer.
item.dc:creator: Taiga Uranaka, Nao Sano

media:content.media:description: Signage for Dai-ichi Life Group in a reception area at the Dai-ichi Life Holdings Inc. and Dai-ichi Life Insurance Co. head office building in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Jan. 19, 2024. Japanese life insurers are the main buyers of domestic sovereign bonds due in more than 10 years and typically increase purchases toward the end of the fiscal year. They are holding off as the earthquake that struck Ishikawa Prefecture on Jan. 1 reduced the likelihood that the BOJ will end negative rates at its meeting on Jan. 23.

item.title: Trump Calls Putin 'Crazy', EU Tariffs Deadline Extended | Bloomberg The Pulse 05/26
item.description:
President Donald Trump said he was “absolutely” considering new sanctions against Russia as Moscow’s deadly campaign of missile and drone strikes across much of Ukraine extended into a third night. Trump’s comments, made to reporters in New Jersey on Sunday before he boarded Air Force One, came as he grows visibly frustrated with Russian President Vladimir Putin and the state of talks meant to deliver a ceasefire in Ukraine. The US president has repeatedly threatened new sanctions in the past without following through. In tariff news, President Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. “We had a very nice call and I agreed to move it,” he said.
Today's guest: Giulia Culot, Sycomore Asset Management Senior Portfolio Manager, Yun Liu, HSBC ASEAN Economist (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Calls Putin 'Crazy', Delays 50% Tariffs on EU Goods | The Opening Trade 05/26
item.description:
President Donald Trump said he was “absolutely” considering new sanctions against Russia as Moscow’s deadly campaign of missile and drone strikes across much of Ukraine extended into a third night. “I’m not happy with what Putin is doing,” Trump said before Moscow’s latest barrage.
Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. The EU had been slated for a 20% tariff under those reciprocal rates announced in April, and a temporary pause took the rate down to 10%.
The Opening Trade has everything you need to know as markets open across Europe. With analysis you won't find anywhere else, we break down the biggest stories of the day and speak to top guests who have skin in the game. Hosted by Guy Johnson and Kriti Gupta. (Source: Bloomberg)
